title: Part A: Thesis
stimulusHtml:
A thesis is an arguable statement about an interpretation of a text.

The thesis may appear anywhere within the essay.

A thesis that meets the criteria can be awarded the point whether or not the rest of the response successfully conveys that line of reasoning.

By this point in the course, students should be pretty far along in terms of the understandings and skills related to rhetorical analysis— especially the necessary argument skills. As such, the thesis should be clear and well-developed, earning a point as one would on the summative (May) AP Exam.
descriptions: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
Responds to the prompt with a defensible thesis that addresses the author’s purpose or signals the line of reasoning.

title: Part B:  Evidence AND Commentary
stimulusHtml:
Writing that suffers from grammatical and/or mechanical errors that interfere with communication cannot earn the fourth point in this row.

Commentary connects the evidence and reasoning to the thesis.

By this point in the course, students should have plenty of experience analyzing and writing about other writers’ rhetorical choices. In addition, they have had many opportunities to practice developing commentary that connects evidence and reasoning in the context of textual analysis. As such, students may earn up to 4 point in this row as they would on the summative (May) AP exam.
descriptions: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
The response meets one of the following criteria:

The response meets both of the following criteria:

Makes textual references (direct quotes or paraphrases) that are relevant to the thesis.

AND

Provides commentary; however, it repeats, oversimplifies, or misinterprets the cited information or evidence.

The response meets both of the following criteria:

Makes textual references (direct quotes or paraphrases) that are relevant to the thesis.

AND

Provides commentary that explains the relationship between evidence and the thesis; however, commentary is uneven, limited, or incomplete.

The response meets both of the following criteria:

Makes textual references (direct quotes or paraphrases) that are relevant to the thesis.

AND

Provides well-developed commentary that consistently and explicitly explains the relationship between the evidence and the thesis.

title: Part C:  Sophistication
stimulusHtml:
Demonstrates sophistication of thought and/or a complex understanding of the rhetorical situation by:

1. Explaining the significance or relevance of the text’s purpose within a broader context.

2. Engaging in concession, rebuttal, and/or refutation of other arguments relating to the thesis.

3. Recognizing and accounting for contradictions or complexities within the text.

4. Making effective rhetorical choices that strengthen the force and impact of the student’s argument.

5. Utilizing a prose style that is especially vivid, persuasive, convincing, or appropriate to the student’s argument.

By this point in the course, students should already have sufficient experience with argument to demonstrate many of the forms of rhetorical sophistication outlined above. In addition, the reading passages and multiple-choice questions in Unit 7 are designed to encourage students to consider qualifications and complexities in texts and should help them recognize and explain such complexities in the stimulus for this Rhetorical Analysis task. This row earns a point as it would on the summative (May) AP exam.
descriptions: Response does not demonstrate sophistication of thought and/or a complex understanding of the rhetorical situation.
Response demonstrates sophistication of thought and/or a complex understanding of the rhetorical situation.
